skill.name: shell-scripting
skill.description: Specialized knowledge of Bash and Zsh scripting, shell automation, command-line tools, and scripting best practices. Use when the user needs to write, debug, or optimize shell scripts, work with command-line tools, automate tasks with bash/zsh, or asks for shell script help.
skill.summary: Specialized knowledge of Bash and Zsh scripting, shell automation, command-line tools, and scripting...
skill.author: CodingKaiser

security_audit.summary: This is a pure knowledge skill containing documentation and reference patterns for shell scripting. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, no external commands. Content includes security best practices like avoiding eval with untrusted input and using mktemp for temporary files.

content.value_statement: Shell scripts often fail due to unquoted variables, missing error handling, and unsafe patterns. This skill provides production-ready templates, security-aware best practices, and modern command-line alternatives to help you write maintainable Bash and Zsh scripts.
actual_capabilities: Provide production-ready script templates with proper error handling
Recommend safe shell patterns (quoting, input validation, mktemp)
Show modern CLI alternatives like ripgrep, fd, and jq
Explain Zsh-specific features and advanced globbing
Demonstrate robust file iteration and array operations
limitations: Does not execute shell commands on your system
Does not install or configure development environments
Does not access or modify your files
Does not run external programs or scripts

use_cases.title: Automate deployment tasks
use_cases.description: Build robust automation scripts with proper trap handlers and signal management.

use_cases.title: Manage systems efficiently
use_cases.description: Use efficient file processing, process management, and text manipulation techniques.

prompt_templates.title: Basic script structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the proper header and structure for a Bash script using best practices.

prompt_templates.title: Safe error handling
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I use set -euo pipefail, traps, and proper exit codes for robust error handling?

prompt_templates.title: File processing
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Bash function to safely iterate through files with spaces in names using null delimiters.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-shell compatibility
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a script template that works in both Bash and Zsh with conditional Zsh-specific features.

output_examples.input: Write a Bash script to process log files safely
output: Start with proper shebang and safe options: #!/usr/bin/env bash, set -euo pipefail
Use null-delimited iteration: while IFS= read -r -d '' file
Add trap for cleanup: trap cleanup EXIT

best_practices: Always quote variables: "$variable" not $variable to handle spaces and special characters
Use set -euo pipefail at the script start to catch errors early
Validate command existence with command -v before using external tools
anti_patterns: Do not parse ls output; use globs or find with -print0 instead
Avoid eval with untrusted input; it enables code injection attacks
Do not use unquoted variables; they cause word splitting on spaces

faq.question: What shells does this skill cover?
faq.answer: Primary focus is Bash and Zsh. Most patterns apply to both with minor adjustments.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes. It provides guidance only and never executes code or accesses your system.

faq.question: Does this run shell commands?
faq.answer: No. This is a knowledge skill that provides templates and best practices.

faq.question: Can I learn shell scripting from this?
faq.answer: Yes. It covers fundamentals, best practices, and includes production-ready templates.

faq.question: Does it install CLI tools?
faq.answer: No. It recommends modern tools like ripgrep but does not install anything.

faq.question: How is this different from documentation?
faq.answer: It curates practical patterns, security-aware practices, and ready-to-use templates.
